title: 109_hr60
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tsunamis Temporary Protected Status Act of 2005". On December 26, 2004, a 9.0 magnitude earthquake triggered tsunamis affecting countries in South and Southeast Asia. It was the fourth largest earthquake since 1900, causing widespread destruction in Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand, and other Asian regions. The 2004 earthquake triggered tsunamis in Myanmar, Malaysia, Maldives, Tanzania, Seychelles, Bangladesh, and Kenya, with waves up to 50 feet high. Over 2.6 million people were displaced, tens of thousands are missing, and over 140,000 deaths have been reported in Indonesia and Sri Lanka. The 2004 earthquake and tsunamis caused over 154,800 deaths in India, Thailand, and Maldives. The United Nations declared it the costliest relief operation ever, with reconstruction estimated to take 5 to 10 years. The earthquake, aftershocks, and flooding hindered food and supply delivery. Designation to render nationals of Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand, Somalia, Myanmar, Malaysia, Maldives, Tanzania, Seychelles, Bangladesh, and Kenya eligible for Temporary Protected Status. Designation of Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand, Somalia, Myanmar, Malaysia, Maldives, Tanzania, Seychelles, Bangladesh, and Kenya for Temporary Protected Status under Immigration and Nationality Act. Initial designation period is 1 year. Aliens from these countries eligible for TPS. Aliens from Somalia, Myanmar, Malaysia, Maldives, Tanzania, Seychelles, Bangladesh, and Kenya can qualify for Temporary Protected Status if they meet certain requirements, including continuous physical presence in the United States since the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security must approve travel abroad for aliens granted TPS. Aliens granted temporary protected status can request authorization for a brief trip abroad due to emergency circumstances. Upon returning to the United States, they will be treated the same as other returning aliens with TPS status.
